Okie doke, the "right now" fix is testing on this PR (https://github.com/instabase/instabase/pull/71124)

It does *temporarily* disable the `python-unit-tests` pre-commit check, because that script regenerates the relevant commands files that determine how each module's tests are run. This regeneration is non-conditional, it seems, so even once the band-aid fix is merged to master, the next commit anyone tries will both fail _and_ rebuild the files, thus rebreaking Bazel Python tests.

Doing this "scalpel" work in the labyrinthian `run_tests_for_affected_code.py` script is either nonviable or too slow to solve right now, so as a break-fix this is the solution - a lumberjack fix while we wait for the surgeon, if you will. :smile:

Having found a bit of breathing room I have some breathing room to give a bit of context about why I want this fixed forward and not reverted, and hopefully give a more succinct explanation of what's happening here.

Bazel's `rules_python` code, when building up a context in which to run unit tests, accumulates every directory containing any files needed for the requested tests into the `PYTHONPATH` environment variable.
This includes:
• Path to every package containing our code for which we are running one more unit tests.
• Path to every package *direct* *dependency* package, internal or external.
• Path to every package *indirect dependency*, internal or external - for _*every dependency*_, direct or indirect.
For reference, we currently define in `third-party/bazel/py/requirements_py39.in` , *136* direct dependencies.

When we run `pip-compile` to find all transitive dependencies based on that file, we build `third-party/bazel/py/requirements_py39_linux.txt`, with *269* total dependencies.

To demonstrate, I build a suuuuper tiny little bazel-enabled py-util, `cody-debug` , that just has a single code file, and runs a single test. The 'application code' is just two lines, and lists no direct dependencies, while it's single unit test depends only on the module code being tested, at least per the BUILD.bazel files. Running bazel test on that contrived example from a clean workspace yields:

• Entries: 45
• Components of every entry:
• Prefix: `/home/owner/.cache/bazel/_bazel_owner/9fc0e062b1d93ceecdd77e6ee927b893/sandbox/processwrapper-sandbox/3/execroot/__main__/bazel-out/k8-fastbuild/bin/`
    ◦ Size: `149` bytes (increases with sandbox counter int)
• Code path: `shared-utils/py-utils/cody-account-utils/test/unit/py/instabase/cody_account_utils/`
    ◦ Size: `83` bytes (direct correlate to path length in our repo)
• runfiles path: `cody_account_utils_test.runfiles/`
    ◦ Size: `33` bytes (linear correlate to length of our Bazel rule labels)
• Bazel-ified package name+path for the depedency: `pypi_deps_backoff/site-packages`
        ▪︎ Sizes for my example: Smallest == `267` bytes, largest == `359` bytes
• Largest is, predictably, the reference to the test's target code for which we're... running tests...
    ◦ `/home/owner/.cache/bazel/_bazel_owner/9fc0e062b1d93ceecdd77e6ee927b893/sandbox/processwrapper-sandbox/3869/execroot/__main__/bazel-out/k8-fastbuild/bin/shared-utils/py-utils/cody-account-utils/test/unit/py/instabase/cody_account_utils/cody_account_utils_test.runfiles/__main__/shared-utils/py-utils/cody-account-utils/test/unit/py/instabase/cody_account_utils`

In comparison, quick stats for our _actual_ (and fairly simple) `account-utils` test run:
• Entries: `181`
• Shortest entry is `253` bytes, longest is `335`
• Total `PYTHONPATH` size is `51,910` bytes, ~52 KB. :sob:
And that's a small one. :upside_down_face:

2. So, there's a lot of really irritating stuff about Linux, and it turns out, the sysconf parameter `SC_NL_ARGMAX` just might be one of them. :upside_down_face: 
I remembered seeing the option to query sysconf parameters via Python's `os.sysconf()` function, but I didn't know the names to pass it for sure - so `os.sysconf_names` to the rescue.
That yields a list of 130+ parameters, but the interesting ones were:
```[...]
  "SC_ARG_MAX": 0,
[...]
  "SC_NL_ARGMAX": 119,
[...]```
Seemed odd that `SC_ARG_MAX` is effectively 'unlimited', but I hadn't seen the `SC_NL_ARGMAX` one in a hot minute.

Well for the curious - the exactly limit, determined by way of "change stuff til it breaks", is precisely *`0.125` MB,* or *`131,060` bytes.*

And some _extra_ fun facts:
• Only environment variables contribute to this particular issue.
• The limit applies to *each* environment variable independently:
    ◦ A `PYTHONPATH` env var of 131,060 bytes will work
    ◦ A `MYOTHERVAR` env var of 131,060 bytes will work
    ◦ Setting BOTH of those env vars, at 131,060 bytes *each* will work
    ◦ Bumping either of those env vars to 131,06*1* bytes will fail with `Argument list too long`
• The total path entries doesn't matter, only total byte count.
• The length of the env var's _name_ contributes to the total size limit, but that's not optional in Python anyway (and would only save 9 Bytes max :joy:)
• It's a kernel limit, NOT made more restrictive by Python itself - setting any env var in my crafting box to one byte over this limit yields `Argument list too long`
:upside_down_face:

The most fun fact? For `refiner-utils`, the only headroom we had prior to the Otel change was a whopping *`1,526` bytes.* :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing: 

And at the average path length of ~242 bytes (on my crafting box anyway), that meant we could add between 4 and 6 new dependency packages, direct or indirect, before it would tip over.

Turns out this is from a kernel parameter, MAX_ARG_STRLEN (https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/include/uapi/linux/binfmts.h#L15C1-L15C40), calculated as `PAGE_SIZE * 32`
And `PAGE_SIZE` on most any linux environment ever is `4096` bytes, and I _think_ it's non-configurable on 64-bit architectures... but I might be misremembering
```─> getconf PAGE_SIZE
4096```
So we end up with...
```PAGE_SIZE = 4096
MAX_ARG_STRLEN = 32 * PAGE_SIZE => 131,072
MAX_ARG_KB = MAX_ARG_STRLEN / 1024 => 128```
And if we consider that the ENTIRE env var definition is a single string counted toward that limit:
```len("PYTHONPATH") == 10
len("=") == 1
len($PYTHONPATH) == 131060
len("\0") == 1```
We get `10 + 1 + 131060 + 1 == 131,072 bytes`
